title: Wesfarmers-backed start-up soars amid personalisation boom
text:
The Kmart program comes five months after OTG's software was launched online and in-store in Officeworks, enabling customers to order and design customised uniforms, sports apparel and team clothing online.

It follows a similar white-label agreement and joint venture with the Workwear Group, which owns Totally Workwear, Hard Yakka and King Gee and supplies uniforms for corporates including Qantas, BHP and Bunnings.

ONTHGO founder Mick Spencer. Supplied

Mr Spencer says OTG is also working with Kmart on plans to sell customised homewares, such as beach towels and pillowcases. The retailer is taking advantage of the growing popularity of personalisation, which has been used in recent years to sell products such as Nutella, Vegemite and Toblerone.

No.1 trend

Customisation is the number one trend in retail. The addressable market is estimated to be worth $1.5 billion in Australia, while the global print-on-demand market in apparel is estimated to be worth $US90 billion ($133 billion) and growing 12 per cent a year, according to a report by US investment bank ComCap.

"OTG has done very well in apparel like uniforms, sportswear and accessories like bags and headwear," Mr Spencer said. "Now that our model is able to do one-unit minimum orders it's opened us up to a quite a substantial new market in giftware and home living."

OTG's sales rose 40 per cent last year and are forecast to rise more than 150 per cent this year.

Advertisement

"Wesfarmers is a big part of the business but they're not everything – our website also continues to grow and we're onboarding more and more customers each day in our core channels," he said.

"More and more customers want to do this online themselves – 55 per cent of Generation Z want the ability to design something nobody else owns and one in five customers are willing to pay a 20 per cent premium for personalised products," he said, citing the ComCap report.

"Now it's just about managing what we have on our plate and we have had to say no to a lot of big partners who have come to us."

OTG recently acquired a small company which makes customised team apparel in regional NSW and a factory in western Sydney to make products that need to be delivered faster than the usual two-week turnaround.

Mr Spencer says the company is considering raising capital to fund the next stage of growth and technology deployments after being approached by potential investors over the past 12 months.
description: After white-label deals with Officeworks and Wesfarmers' workwear unit, the customised apparel start-up's technology is going into Kmart.
